contents: Short title: US - Gasoline. Procedural matters. The Clean Air Act and its implementation. The Reformulated Gasoline Programme. The Conventional Gasoline Programme. Baseline establishment rules: Domestic refiners; Blenders; Importers. The panel report: Its finds and conclusions. Issues raised in this Appeal: The claim of error by the United States. The claim of the appellees and the arguments of the third participants (European Communities and Norway). The preliminary question. The issue of justification under Article XX.g of the General Agreement. The introductory provisions of Article XX of the General Agreement: Applying the Chapeau of the General exception. Findings and conclusions.

title_en: European Communities - EC Measures Concerning Meat and Meat Products (Hormones) - AB-1997-4 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Communautés européennes - Mesures communautaires concernant les viandes et les produits carnés (hormones) - Ab-1997-4 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Medidas que afectan a la carne y los productos cárnicos (hormonas) - Ab-1997-4 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: EC - Hormones (US) ; EC - Hormones (Canada). Introduction: Statement of the appeal. Arguments of the participants and third participants: Claims of error by the European Communities - Appellant. Arguments by the United States - Appellee. Arguments by Canada - Appellee. Claims of error by the United States - Appellant. Claims of error by Canada - Appellant. Arguments by the European Communities - Appellee. Arguments by the third participants: Australia, New Zealand and Norway. Issues raised in this appeal. Allocating the burden of proof in proceedings under the SPS Agreement. The standard of review applicable in proceedings under the SPS Agreement. The relevance of the precautionary principle in the interpretation of the SPS Agreement. Application of the SPS Agreement to measures enacted before 1 January 1995. The requirement of objective assessment of the facts by a panel under Article 11 of the DSU. Certain procedures adopted by the panel. The interpretation of Articles 3.1 and 3.3 of the SPS Agreement. The reading of Articles 5.1 and 5.2 of the SPS Agreement: Basing SPS measures on a risk assessment: The interpretation of "risk assessment". The interpretation of "based on". The reading of Article 5.5 of the SPS Agreement: Consistency of levels of protection and resulting discrimination or disguised restriction on international trade. Appeals by the United States and Canada: Article 2.2 and Article 5.6 of the SPS Agreement. Findings and conclusions.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: meat

Effective of the restriction. Article 2 of the ATC. A member must endeavour to accept recommendations of the TMB. Nullification or impairment of benefits. Interim review. The issue of backdating the effectivity of a transitional safeguard measure taken under Article 6.10 of the ATC: Interpreting Article 6.10 of the ATC: Textual and contextual considerations and the principle of effectiveness. The problem of a speculative "flood of imprts" upon notice of a call for consultations. The issue of applicability of Article XIII.3.b, General Agreement, to a transitional safeguard measure taken under Article 6.10, ATC. title_en: European Communities - Regime for the Importation, Sale and Distribution of Bananas - Recourse to Article 21.5 by Ecuador - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Communautés européennes - Régime applicable à l'importation, à la vente et à la distribution des bananes - Recours de l'Équateur à l'article 21.5 - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Régimen para la importación, venta y distribución de bananos - Recurso al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 por el Ecuador - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: EEC - Bananas III (Ecuador). 
Introduction. Factual aspects: Access quantities and country allocations. Tariff treatment. Administrative aspects of the banana import regime. Lomé waiver. Procedural issues. Main arguments: General. Issues related to the GATT: Article I issues. Article XIII issues. Issues related to the GATS. Conclusion. Arguments by third parties: Brazil, Cameroon and Côte d'Ivoire: Issues related to the GATT. Issues related to the GATS. The Caribbean States: Issues related to the GATT. Issues related to the GATS. Colombia: Article XIII issues. Costa Rica: Issues related to the GATT. Ecuador's response to third parties. Findings: Working procedures and timetable. Terms of reference. Article XIII of GATT 1994: The 857,700 tonnes reserved for traditional imports from ACP countries. Ecuador's share of the MFN tariff quota. Article I of GATT 1994: The Lomé waiver. The requirements of the Lomé Convention. Preferences for traditional ACP imports. Preferential tariffs for non-traditional ACP banana imports. GATS issues: The scope of the European Communities' commitments on "wholesale trade services". Licence allocation procedures. The rules for "newcomer" licences. General observations. Suggestions on implementation. Summary. Concluding remark. Conclusions. Annex 1: "Pre-1991 best-ever" imports of bananas into the European Communities from traditional ACP supplying countries. Annex II: Ecuador's share of total European Communities banana imports from all sources. Ecuador's share of world exports. Ecuador's share of world banana exports other than to the European Communities. Annex III: Prior European Communities system: Operator categories under the tariff quota for third-country/non-traditional ACP imports. Prior European Communities system: Activity functions under the tariff quota for third-country/non-traditional ACP imports.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: bananas

title_en: Australia - Measures Affecting Importation of Salmon - Recourse to Article 21.5 by Canada - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Australie - Mesures visant les importations de saumons - Recours du Canada à l'article 21.5 - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Australia - Medidas que afectan a la importación de salmón - Recurso al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 por el Canadá - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents: Short title: Australia - Salmon. Introduction: Terms of reference. Panel composition (membership). Factual aspects: General. The 1999 import risk analyses. Measures regarding imports of fresh chilled or frozen salmon from Canada. Measures regarding imports of non-viable, non-salmonid finfish. Measures regarding imports of live ornamental finfish. Tasmania's restrictions on salmonid imports. Claims of the parties. Summary of main arguments of the parties: Introduction: Australia. Canada. Terms of reference. The Tasmanian measure. Due process. Measures to comply with the recommendations and rulings of the DSB. Article 5.1 of the SPS Agreement. Article 5.5. Article 5.6. Article 2.3. Article 8 and Annex C. Summary of third party submissions: European Communities. Norway. United States. Panel consultation with scientific experts: Panel procedures with regard to scientific expertise. Questions to the exports - Compiled responses. Findings: Claims of the parties. Preliminary issues. "The existence... of measures taken to comply with the recommendations and rulings" of the DSB in the sense of Article 21.5 of the DSU. Sanitary measures based on a risk assessment pursuant to Article 5.1 of the SPS Agreement. Arbitrary or unjustifiable distinctions in appropriate levels of protection in the sense of Article 5.5 of the SPS Agreement. Discrimination in the sense of Article 2.3, first sentence, of the SPS Agreement. Sanitary measures shall not be "more trade-restrictive than required" in the sense of Article 5.6 of the SPS Agreement. Information requirements contrary to paragraph 1(c) of Annex C to the SPS Agreement. The Tasmanian measure on 24 November 1999. Conclusions. Annex 1: Transcript of the Joint Meeting with Experts, held on 8 December 1999. Annex 2: Revised working procedures.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: salmon

contents: Short title: EC - Bananas III (Mexico). Introduction. Procedural issues. Factual aspects. Main arguments: General. Trade in goods: General overview of the case. Detailed arguments: Tariff issues; Allocation issues; Import licensing issues. General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS): Introduction. Issues of scope. Operator category licence allocation. Activity function licence allocation - Articles II and XVII. Hurricane licences - Articles II and XVII. Export certificates - Articles II and XVII. Arguments presented by third parties: ACP third parties; Canada; Colombia, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Venezuela; India; Japan; The Philippines. Interim review. Findings: Organizational issues: Participation of third parties; Presence of private lawyers. Preliminary issues: Adquacy of the consultations; Specificity of the request for panel establishment; Requirement of legal interest; Number of panel reports. Substantive issues: The European Communities market for bananas: Article XIII of GATT. Tariff issues. The European Communities banana import licensing procedures. The European Communities banana import licensing procedures and the GATS. Nullification or impairment. Summary of findings. Final remarks. Conclusions. Attachment.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: bananas

title_en: Brazil - Export Financing Programme for Aircraft - Second Recourse by Canada to Article 21.5 of the DSU - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Brésil - Programme de financement des exportations pour les aéronefs - Deuxième recours du Canada à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Brasil - Programa de financiación de las exportaciones para aeronaves - Segundo recurso del Canadá al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Brazil - Aircraft. Conclusion of the Panel Report: (a) It has not been established that PROEX III, as such, is inconsistent with Article 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement; (b) PROEX III, as such, is, in any event, justified under the second paragraph of item (k) of the Illustrative List of Export Subsidies contained in Annex I to the SCM Agreement; (c) PROEX III, as such, cannot, however, be justified under the first paragraph of item (k) of the Illustrative List of Export Subsidies contained in Annex I to the SCM Agreement. In reaching this conclusion, we once again wish to recall the precise issue which we were called on to resolve.  That issue was whether the PROEX III programme, as such, that is to say, on its face and independently of its application, is inconsistent with the SCM Agreement.  Our conclusion that the PROEX III programme, as such, is not inconsistent with the SCM Agreement is based on the view that it is legally possible for Brazil to operate the PROEX III programme in such a way that it will: (a) Not result in a benefit being conferred on producers of regional aircraft and, hence, not constitute a subsidy within the meaning of Article 1.1 of the SCM Agreement; or (b) Result in a benefit being conferred on producers of regional aircraft, but conform to the requirements of the safe haven of the second paragraph of item (k), in which case it would not constitute a prohibited export subsidy within the meaning of Article 3.1 of the SCM Agreement. We wish to be clear, however, that it does not necessarily follow from our conclusion that future application of the PROEX III programme will, likewise, be consistent with the SCM Agreement.  It should be mentioned, in this regard, that Canada is free to challenge such future application in accordance with the provisions of the DSU if it considers it not to be in conformity with the SCM Agreement.

Contents of the Report:

I. Procedural background. II. Factual aspects. III. Procedural issue. IV. Interim review. A. Comments by Canada. B. Comments by Brazil. V. Findings. A. Measure at issue and task of the panel. B. Review of legislation per se. C. Overview of the parties' arguments. D. Article 3 of the SCM Agreement. 1. General. 2. Examination of PROEX III. (a) financial contribution by a government. (b) conferral of a benefit. (i) structure and design of PROEX III. (ii) CIRR as minimum interest rate. (iii) international market benchmark. (iv) mandatory versus discretionary conferral of a benefit. (c) export contingency. 3. Conclusion. E. Second paragraph of item (k). 1. Burden of proof. 2. Specific interpretative issues. (a) "export credit practices". (b) "relevant international undertaking on official export credits". (c) "conformity with the interest rates provisions of the relevant undertaking". 3. Examination of PROEX III. (a) the distinction between mandatory and discretionary legislation in the context of an affirmative defence. (b) applicability of the second paragraph of item (k). (c) conformity with the interest rates provisions of the 1998 oecd arrangement. (i) interest rates provisions. Article 22 of Annex III.(on minimum interest rates). Article 16 (on the construction of CIRRs) and Article 17 (on the application of CIRRs). Articles 18 and 19 (on official support for cosmetic interest rates). (ii) provisions supporting or reinforcing the interest rates provisions. Article 7 (on minimum cash payments). Article 13 (on repayment of principal) and Article 14 (on payment of interest). Articles 20 - 24 (on minimum premium benchmarks). Article 25 (on local costs) and Article 26 (on maximum validity periods for export credit terms). Article 19 of Annex III.(on best endeavours). Article 21 of Annex III.(on maximum repayment terms). Article 23 of Annex III.(on insurance premium and guarantee fees) and Article 24 of Annex III.(on aid support). Article 28a) of Annex III.(on used aircraft). Article 29a) of Annex III.(on spare engines and spare parts ordered with aircraft). 4. Conclusion. F. First paragraph of item (k). 1. General. 2. Payment of the costs incurred in obtaining credits. 3. Material advantage. (a) appropriate benchmark. (i) appropriateness of the CIRR alone. (ii) appropriateness of a benchmark other than the CIRR. (b) examination of PROEX III. 4. A contrario use of the first paragraph of item (k). 5. Conclusion. VI. Conclusion.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Second Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: aircraft parts

Contents of the Report:

I. Procedural background. II. Factual aspects. III. Procedural issue. IV. Interim review. A. Comments by Canada. B. Comments by Brazil. V. Findings. A. Measure at issue and task of the panel. B. Review of legislation per se. C. Overview of the parties' arguments. D. Article 3 of the SCM Agreement. 1. General. 2. Examination of PROEX III. (a) financial contribution by a government. (b) conferral of a benefit. (i) structure and design of PROEX III. (ii) CIRR as minimum interest rate. (iii) international market benchmark. (iv) mandatory versus discretionary conferral of a benefit. (c) export contingency. 3. Conclusion. E. Second paragraph of item (k). 1. Burden of proof. 2. Specific interpretative issues. (a) "export credit practices". (b) "relevant international undertaking on official export credits". (c) "conformity with the interest rates provisions of the relevant undertaking". 3. Examination of PROEX III. (a) the distinction between mandatory and discretionary legislation in the context of an affirmative defence. (b) applicability of the second paragraph of item (k). (c) conformity with the interest rates provisions of the 1998 oecd arrangement. (i) interest rates provisions. Article 22 of Annex III.(on minimum interest rates). Article 16 (on the construction of CIRRs) and Article 17 (on the application of CIRRs). Articles 18 and 19 (on official support for cosmetic interest rates). (ii) provisions supporting or reinforcing the interest rates provisions. Article 7 (on minimum cash payments). Article 13 (on repayment of principal) and Article 14 (on payment of interest). Articles 20 - 24 (on minimum premium benchmarks). Article 25 (on local costs) and Article 26 (on maximum validity periods for export credit terms). Article 19 of Annex III.(on best endeavours). Article 21 of Annex III.(on maximum repayment terms). Article 23 of Annex III.(on insurance premium and guarantee fees) and Article 24 of Annex III.(on aid support). Article 28a) of Annex III.(on used aircraft). Article 29a) of Annex III.(on spare engines and spare parts ordered with aircraft). 4. Conclusion. F. First paragraph of item (k). 1. General. 2. Payment of the costs incurred in obtaining credits. 3. Material advantage. (a) appropriate benchmark. (i) appropriateness of the CIRR alone. (ii) appropriateness of a benchmark other than the CIRR. (b) examination of PROEX III. 4. A contrario use of the first paragraph of item (k). 5. Conclusion. VI. Conclusion.

title_en: Brazil - Export Financing Programme for Aircraft - Second Recourse by Canada to Article 21.5 of the DSU - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Brésil - Programme de financement des exportations pour les aéronefs - Deuxième recours du Canada à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Brasil - Programa de financiación de las exportaciones para aeronaves - Segundo recurso del Canadá al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Brazil - Aircraft. Conclusion of the Panel Report: (a) It has not been established that PROEX III, as such, is inconsistent with Article 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement; (b) PROEX III, as such, is, in any event, justified under the second paragraph of item (k) of the Illustrative List of Export Subsidies contained in Annex I to the SCM Agreement; (c) PROEX III, as such, cannot, however, be justified under the first paragraph of item (k) of the Illustrative List of Export Subsidies contained in Annex I to the SCM Agreement. In reaching this conclusion, we once again wish to recall the precise issue which we were called on to resolve.  That issue was whether the PROEX III programme, as such, that is to say, on its face and independently of its application, is inconsistent with the SCM Agreement.  Our conclusion that the PROEX III programme, as such, is not inconsistent with the SCM Agreement is based on the view that it is legally possible for Brazil to operate the PROEX III programme in such a way that it will: (a) Not result in a benefit being conferred on producers of regional aircraft and, hence, not constitute a subsidy within the meaning of Article 1.1 of the SCM Agreement; or (b) Result in a benefit being conferred on producers of regional aircraft, but conform to the requirements of the safe haven of the second paragraph of item (k), in which case it would not constitute a prohibited export subsidy within the meaning of Article 3.1 of the SCM Agreement. We wish to be clear, however, that it does not necessarily follow from our conclusion that future application of the PROEX III programme will, likewise, be consistent with the SCM Agreement.  It should be mentioned, in this regard, that Canada is free to challenge such future application in accordance with the provisions of the DSU if it considers it not to be in conformity with the SCM Agreement.

Contents of the Report:

I. Procedural background. II. Factual aspects. III. Procedural issue. IV. Interim review. A. Comments by Canada. B. Comments by Brazil. V. Findings. A. Measure at issue and task of the panel. B. Review of legislation per se. C. Overview of the parties' arguments. D. Article 3 of the SCM Agreement. 1. General. 2. Examination of PROEX III. (a) financial contribution by a government. (b) conferral of a benefit. (i) structure and design of PROEX III. (ii) CIRR as minimum interest rate. (iii) international market benchmark. (iv) mandatory versus discretionary conferral of a benefit. (c) export contingency. 3. Conclusion. E. Second paragraph of item (k). 1. Burden of proof. 2. Specific interpretative issues. (a) "export credit practices". (b) "relevant international undertaking on official export credits". (c) "conformity with the interest rates provisions of the relevant undertaking". 3. Examination of PROEX III. (a) the distinction between mandatory and discretionary legislation in the context of an affirmative defence. (b) applicability of the second paragraph of item (k). (c) conformity with the interest rates provisions of the 1998 oecd arrangement. (i) interest rates provisions. Article 22 of Annex III.(on minimum interest rates). Article 16 (on the construction of CIRRs) and Article 17 (on the application of CIRRs). Articles 18 and 19 (on official support for cosmetic interest rates). (ii) provisions supporting or reinforcing the interest rates provisions. Article 7 (on minimum cash payments). Article 13 (on repayment of principal) and Article 14 (on payment of interest). Articles 20 - 24 (on minimum premium benchmarks). Article 25 (on local costs) and Article 26 (on maximum validity periods for export credit terms). Article 19 of Annex III.(on best endeavours). Article 21 of Annex III.(on maximum repayment terms). Article 23 of Annex III.(on insurance premium and guarantee fees) and Article 24 of Annex III.(on aid support). Article 28a) of Annex III.(on used aircraft). Article 29a) of Annex III.(on spare engines and spare parts ordered with aircraft). 4. Conclusion. F. First paragraph of item (k). 1. General. 2. Payment of the costs incurred in obtaining credits. 3. Material advantage. (a) appropriate benchmark. (i) appropriateness of the CIRR alone. (ii) appropriateness of a benchmark other than the CIRR. (b) examination of PROEX III. 4. A contrario use of the first paragraph of item (k). 5. Conclusion. VI. Conclusion.

title_sp: Japón - Medidas que afectan a las películas y el papel fotográficos de consumo - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:

title_en: United States - Import Prohibition of Certain Shrimp and Shrimp Products - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by Malaysia - AB-2001-4 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: États-Unis - Prohibition à l'importation de certaines crevettes et de certains produits à base de crevettes - Recours de la Malaisie à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - AB-2001-4 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Prohibición de las importaciones de determinados camarones y productos del camarón - Recurso de Malasia al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - AB-2001-4 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents:
Short title: US - Shrimp.
I. Introduction. II. Arguments of the participants and the third participants. A. Claims of error by Malaysia - appellant. 1. Terms of reference. 2. The chapeau of Article XX of the GATT 1994. B. Arguments of the United States - Appellee. 1. Terms of reference. 2. The chapeau of Article XX of the GATT 1994. C. Arguments of the third participants. 1. Australia. 2. European Communities. 3. Hong Kong, China. 4. India. 5. Japan. 6. Mexico. 7. Thailand. III. Preliminary procedural matter. IV. Issues raised in this appeal. V. Terms of reference. VI. The chapeau of Article XX of the GATT 1994. A. The nature and the extent of the duty of the United States to pursue international cooperation in the protection and conservation of sea turtles. B. The flexibility of the revised guidelines. VII. Findings and conclusions.

Findings and Conclusions: For the reasons set out in this Report, the Appellate Body: finds that the Panel correctly fulfilled its mandate under Article 21.5 of the DSU of examining the consistency, with the relevant provisions of the GATT 1994, of the United States measure taken to comply with the recommendations and rulings of the DSB in  United States - Shrimp;  and upholds the finding of the Panel, in paragraph 6.1 of its Report, that "Section 609 of Public Law 101-162, as implemented by the Revised Guidelines of 8 July 1999 and as applied so far by the [United States] authorities, is justified under Article XX of the GATT 1994 as long as the conditions stated in the findings of this Report, in particular the ongoing serious good faith efforts to reach a multilateral agreement, remain satisfied". As we have upheld the Panel's finding that the United States measure is now applied in a manner that meets the requirements of Article XX of the GATT 1994, we do not make any recommendation to the DSB pursuant to Article 19.1 of the DSU.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: turtles

title_en: United States - Import Prohibition of Certain Shrimp and Shrimp Products - Recourse to Article 21.5 by Malaysia - Report of the Panel
title_fr: États-Unis - Prohibition à l'importation de certaines crevettes et de certains produits à base de crevettes - Recours de la Malaisie à l'article 21:5 - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Prohibición de las importaciones de determinados camarones y productos del camarón - Recurso de Malasia al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents: Short title: US - Shrimp. I. Introduction. A. Terms of reference. B. Panel composition. II. Factual aspects. A.Conservation issues. B. History of the case. 1.Section 609:  the 1996 Guidelines. 2.Panel proceedings. C. Reasonable period of time. D. Implementation. 1.Section 609:  the 1999 Revised Guidelines.  III. Main arguments of the parties. A. Procedural issues. B. Violation of Article XI. C. Justification under Article XX.  1.General comments.  2.Article XX(g). 3.Chapeau.  (a) General compliance issues.  (b)Unjustifiable discrimination. (c) Arbitrary discrimination. (d) Disguised restriction on international trade. IV. Summary of Third party submissions. V. Findings. A. General Approach to the issues before the Panel.  B. Preliminary issues. C. Violation of Article XI:1 of the GATT 1994.  D. Application of Article XX of the GATT 1994.  1.Preliminary remarks. 2. Consistency of the implementing measure with paragraph (g) of Article XX of the GATT 1994.  3. Arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination between countries where the same conditions prevail: the question of international negotiations. 4. Other requirements related to arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination between countries where the same conditions prevail.  5.Disguised restriction on international trade. VI. Conclusions.  VII. concluding remarks. The Panel reaches the following conclusions: (a) The measure adopted by the United States in order to comply with the recommendations and rulings of the DSB violates Article XI.1 of the GATT 1994;  (b) in light of the recommendations and rulings of the DSB, Section 609 of Public Law 101-162, as implemented by the Revised Guidelines of 8 July 1999 and as applied so far by the US authorities, is justified under Article XX of the GATT 1994 as long as the conditions stated in the findings of this Report, in particular the ongoing serious good faith efforts to reach a multilateral agreement, remain satisfied. The Panel urges Malaysia and the United States to cooperate fully in order to conclude as soon a possible an agreement which will permit the protection and conservation of sea turtles to the satisfaction of all interests involved and taking into account the principle that States have common but differentiated responsibilities to conserve and protect the environment.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase

title_en: Argentina - Measures Affecting Imports of Footwear, Textiles, Apparel and other Items - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Argentine - Mesures affectant les importations de chaussures, textiles, vêtements et autres articles - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Argentina - Medidas que afectan a las importaciones de calzado, textiles, prendas de vestir y otros artículos - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Argentina - Textiles and Apparel.
Introduction. Factual aspects: Argentina's import regime for textiles, apparel and footwear. Minimum specific import duties ("DIEM"). Statistical tax. Claims and main arguments: Requests for preliminary rulings by the panel. Violation of Article II in relation to the implementation of Argentina's Schedule LXIV. The statistical tax. Article 7 of the ATC. Third parties submissions: The European Communities, Hungary and India. Interim review. Findings: Preliminary objection by Argentina. Article II of GATT. The statistical tax. Article 7 of the ATC. Conclusions.

title_en: Argentina - Measures Affecting Imports of Footwear, Textiles, Apparel and other Items - AB-1998-1 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Argentine - Mesures affectant les importations de chaussures, textiles, vêtements et autres articles - AB-1998-1 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Argentina - Medidas que afectan a las importaciones de calzado, textiles, prendas de vestir y otros artículos - AB-1998-1 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents:
Short title: Argentina - Textiles and Apparel.
Introduction: Statement of the Appeal. Arguments of the participants and the third participant: Claims of error by Argentina - Appellant. Arguments by the United States - Appellee. Arguments by the European Communities - Third participant. Issues raised in this appeal. Interpretation of Article II of the GATT 1994. Violation of Article II "in all cases". The statistical tax and Argentina's stated commitments to the IMF. Objective assessment of the matter under Article 11 of the DSU: Admission of certain evidence. Consultation with the IMF. Findings and conclusions.

title_en: Indonesia - Certain Measures Affecting the Automobile Industry - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Indonésie - Certaines mesures affectant l'industrie automobile - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Indonesia - Determinadas medidas que afectan a la industria del automóvil - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Indonesia - Autos. 
Introduction: Background. Establishment and membership of the Panel. Information-gathering procedure under Annex V of the SCM Agreement. Panel proceedings. Factual aspects: Tax and tariff treatment in Indonesia of imported completely built-up motor vehicles. Measures at issue. Notifications by Indonesia to WTO Committees. Findings and recommendations requested by the parties: Japan, European Communities, United States and Indonesia. Request for preliminary rulings: Participation of private laywers. Preliminary objection to United States' claim regarding the US$690 million loan to TPN. Business proprietary information. Request from Indonesia for termination of the panel with respect to the National Car Programme. Claims under Article III of GATT 1994: Claims under Article III.2, first sentence of GATT 1994. Claims under Article III.2, second sentence of GATT 1994. Claims under Article III.4 of GATT 1994. General response by Indonesia to claims under Article III of GATT 1994-SCM Agreement prevails. Rebuttals to Indonesia's general response to the claims raised under Article III of GATT 1994. Additional arguments regarding the claims under Article III.4 of GATT 1994 pertaining to the tariff measures. Claims under the TRIMS Agreement. Article I.1 claims. Claims under the SCM Agreement: Existence of specific subsidies. Serious prejudice claims. Claims under Article 28 of the SCM Agreement. Article X claims: Claims under Article X.3.a of GATT 1994. Claims under Article X.1 of GATT 1994. Additional arguments regarding whether the June 1996 Programme is an expired measure, and the implications if so. Claims raised under the TRIPs Agreement. Third party arguments: India and Korea. Interim review. Findings: Preliminary rulings. Claims. Is the SCM Agreement the only "Applicable Law" to this dispute? Claims of local content requirements. Claims of tax discrimination. Claims of MFN discrimination. Claims of inadequate publication and partial administration. Claims of serious prejudice under Part III of the SCM Agreement. Claims under Article 28 of the SCM Agreement. Claims under the TRIPS Agreement. Conclusions and recommendation.

title_en: India - Patent Protection for Pharmaceutical and Agricultural Chemical Products - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Inde - Protection conférée par un brevet pour les produits pharmaceutiques et les produits chimiques pour l'agriculture - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: India - Protección mediante patente de los productos farmacéuticos y los productos químicos para la agricultura - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: India - Patents (US).
On the basis of the findings, the Panel concludes that India has not complied with its obligations under Article 70.8(a) and, in the alternative, paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 63 of the TRIPS Agreement, because it has failed to establish a mechanism that adequately preserves novelty and priority in respect of applications for product patents in respect of pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical inventions during the transitional period to which it is entitled under Article 65 of the Agreement, and to publish and notify adequately information about such a mechanism;  and that India has not complied with its obligations under Article 70.9 of the TRIPS Agreement, because it has failed to establish a system for the grant of exclusive marketing rights.

The Panel recommends that the Dispute Settlement Body request India to bring its transitional regime for patent protection of pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical products into conformity with its obligations under the TRIPS Agreement.  The Panel further suggests that, in establishing a mechanism that preserves novelty and priority in respect of applications for product patents in respect of pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical inventions during the transitional period, India should take into account the interests of those persons who would have filed patent applications had an appropriate mechanism been maintained since the expiry of the Patents Ordinance 1994, as well as those who have already filed such applications under that Ordinance or the administrative practices currently in place.

Introduction. Factual aspects. Findings and recommendations requested by the Parties. Arguments of the Parties. Arguments presented by third party: European Communities and their Member States. Interim review. Findings: Claims of the Parties. Procedural issues. Interpretation of the TRIPS Agreement. Article 70.8. Article 63. Article 70.9. Suggestions by the Panel. Conclusions. Annex 1: India, The Patents Act, 1970, No. 39 of 1970, Section 2(1)(j), 2(1)(1), 5-12 and 15. Annex 2: Lok Sabha, Unstarred Questions No. 2601 and answer by the Minister of Industry. Annex 3: Letter of 2 May 1997 from Dr. Harvey E. Bale, Jr., Ph.D., Senior Vice-President International, PhRMA, Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America to The Honourable Charlene Barshefsky, United States Trade Representative.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: pharmaceutical products

title_en: Canada - Measures Affecting the Export of Civilian Aircraft - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Canada - Mesures visant l'exportation des aéronefs civils - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Canadá - Medidas que afectan a la exportación de aeronaves civiles - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Canada - Aircraft.
Introduction. Factual aspects. Findings and recommendations requested by the parties. Requests for preliminary rulings: Canada's request regarding the Panel's jurisdication. Request of Canada for preliminary finding on jurisdiction: The SCM Agreement does not apply to contributions and transactions that took place before the entry into force of the WTO Agreement. Brazil's request regarding additional fact finding. Canada's request for a deadline for the submission of new evidence. Brazil's request regarding deadline for submission of new evidence. Arguments concerning the submission of evidence in response to Panel questions posed in connection with the second meeting. Procedures for protection of business confidential information. Arguments of the parties regarding legal issues concerning SCM Articles 1 and 3: General. "Subsidy" per SCM Article 1. "Contingent, in law or in fact, .. on export performance". Arguments of parties regarding canadian measures alleged by Brazil to be prohibited export subsidies in the sense of SCM Articles 1 and 3: Export Development Corporation ("EDC"). Technology Partnerships Canada ("TPC") and predecessor Defence Industry Productivity Programme ("DIPP"). Sale by Ontario of ownership share in De Havilland. Canada-Québec Subsidiary Agreement on Industrial Development. Société de Développement Industrial du Québec ("SDI"). Arguments regarding the Finan Report by Brazil. Arguments regarding the Clark Report. Arguments of third parties: European Communities. Submission of the United States. Interim review. Findings: Introduction. Preliminary issues. Definition of "subsidy" within the meaning of Article 1 of the SCM Agreement. Export Development Corporation. Canada Account. Sale to Bombardier by the Ontario Aerospace Corporation of a 49 per cent interest in De Havilland Inc. Benefits provided under the Canada-Quebec Subsidiary Agreements on Industrial Development. Société de développement industriel du Quebec. Technology Partnerships Canada and DIPP. Conclusions and recommendations. Annex 1: Procedures governing business confidential information and declaration of non-disclosure. Annex II: Declaration of non-disclosure.

title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Medidas que afectan a ciertos productos de mantequilla - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: EC - Butter.
The Panel takes note of the mutually agreed solution between the parties to the dispute and of the provisions of Article 12.7 of the DSU which provides that "Where a settlement of the matter among the parties to the dispute has been found, the report of the panel shall be confined to a brief description of the case and to reporting that a solution has been reached."  Accordingly, the Panel concludes its work by reporting that a mutually agreed solution to this dispute has been reached between the parties.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: butter

title_en: India - Patent Protection for Pharmaceutical and Agricultural Chemical Products - Complaint by the European Communities and Their Member States - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Inde - Protection conférée par un brevet pour les produits pharmaceutiques et les produits chimiques pour l'agriculture - Plainte des Communautés européennes et de leurs États membres - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: India - Protección mediante patente de los productos farmacéuticos y los productos químicos para la agricultura - Reclamación de las Comunidades Europeas y sus Estados miembros - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: India - Patents (EC). 
On the basis of the findings, the Panel concludes that India has not complied with its obligations under Article 70.8(a) because it has failed to establish a sound legal basis for adequately preserving novelty and priority in respect of applications for product patents in respect of pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical inventions during the transitional period to which it is entitled under Article 65 of the TRIPS Agreement;  and that India has not complied with its obligations under Article 70.9 of the TRIPS Agreement because it has failed to establish a system for the grant of exclusive marketing rights.

The Panel recommends that the Dispute Settlement Body request India to bring its transitional regime for patent protection of pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical products into conformity with its obligations under the TRIPS Agreement.

Introduction. Factual aspects. Findings and recommendations requested by the Parties. Arguments of the Parties. Arguments presented by third party: United States. Interim review. Findings: Claims of the parties. Procedural issues. The extent of the binding nature of precedents. Article 70.8.a of the TRIPS Agreement. Article 70.9 of the TRIPS Agreement. Nullification or impairment. Concluding remarks. Conclusions. Annex 1: Request for the establishment of a panel by the European Communities (WT/DS79/2). Annex 2: Lok Sabha, Unstarred Question No. 2601 and answer by the Minister of Industry. Annex 3: India, The Patents Act, 1970, No. 39 of 1970, Sections 2(1)(j), 2(1)(1), 5-12 and 15. Annex 4: Fax,  dated 28 April 1998, from Dr. Alan Kesketch, Manager, Global Intellectual Property, Glaxo Wellcome.

title_en: United States - Anti-Dumping Duty on Dynamic Random Access Memory Semiconductors (DRAMs) of One Megabit or Above from Korea - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by Korea - Report of the Panel
title_fr: États-Unis - Droit antidumping sur les semi-conducteurs pour mémoires RAM dynamiques (DRAM) de un mégabit ou plus, originaires de Corée - Recours de la Corée à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Imposición de derechos antidumping a los semiconductores para memorias dinámicas de acceso aleatorio (DRAM) de un megabit como mínimo procedentes de Corea - Recurso de Corea al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: US - DRAMS (Article 21.5 - Korea) - Dispute concerns the United States' implementation of the 19 March 1999 Dispute Settlement Body ("DSB") recommendation on United States - Anti-Dumping Duty on Dynamic Random Access Memory Semiconductors (DRAMs) of One Megabit or Above from Korea (WT/DS99/R) ("United States - DRAMs"), whereby the United States was requested to bring section 353.25(a)(2)(ii) of the United States Department of Commerce ("DOC") regulations, and the Final Results Third Review, into conformity with its obligations under Article 11.2 of the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994 ("AD Agreement").
4. At the meeting of the DSB held on 25 April 2000, Korea asserted that the United States had failed to comply with the DSB's recommendations and rulings.  First, instead of adopting a standard conforming to the Panel's findings and rulings, the United States had adopted a very general standard that could be, and in fact had been, misapplied.  Second, in applying the modified standard for revocation, the United States had continued to apply the anti-dumping order to Korean DRAMs without demonstrating by substantial, positive evidence that the anti-dumping duty order needed to be maintained in order to offset dumping, as required by the Panel.  Third, by failing to publish the Final Results Third Review  in the Federal Register, the United States had failed to meet its obligations under Article X:1 of the GATT 1994 and Article 12.3 of the AD Agreement. On 20 October 2000, pursuant to Article 3.6 of the DSU, the parties notified the DSB of a mutually agreed solution to the matter under review by the Panel.  The parties' notification was circulated as document WT/DS99/12. The Panel takes note of this mutually agreed solution between the parties to the dispute and of Article 12.7 of the DSU, which provides in relevant part that "where a settlement of the matter among the parties to the dispute has been found, the report of the panel shall be confined to a brief description of the case and to reporting that a solution has been reached".  Accordingly, the Panel concludes its work by reporting that a mutually agreed solution to this dispute has been reached between the parties.

title_en: Korea - Definitive Safeguard Measure on Imports of Certain Dairy Products - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Corée - Mesure de sauvegarde définitive appliquée aux importations de certains produits laitiers - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Corea - Medida de salvaguardia definitiva impuesta a las importaciones de determinados productos lácteos - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Korea - Dairy.
Introduction: Background. Establishment and membership of the panel. Panel proceedings. Factual aspects. Findings and recommendations requested by the Parties: European Communities and Korea. Main arguments of the Parties: Procedural objections. Subsidiary issues. Claim under Article XIX.1.a of GATT. Claim under Article XIX.1.a of GATT and Article 2.1 of the Agreement on Safeguards. Korea's application of safeguards measures to agricultural products. Claim under Article 4.2.a of the Agreement on Safeguards. Claim under Article 4.2.b of the Agreement on Safeguards. Claims under Article 5.1 of the Agreement on Safeguards. Claims under Article 12 of the Agreement on Safeguard. Third party arguments: United States. Interim review. Findings: Procedural matters. Burden of proof. Standard of review. General principles of interpretation. Claims under Article XIX of GATT. Violation of Article 2.1 of the Agreement on Safeguards - Failure to analyse "under such conditions". Claims under Article 4.2 of the Agreement on Safeguards. Claims under Article 5.1 of the Agreement on Safeguards. Claims under Article 12. Conclusions and recommendations.

title_en: Canada - Measures Affecting the Importation of Milk and the Exportation of Dairy Products - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by New Zealand and the United States - AB-2001-6 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Canada - Mesures visant l'importation de lait et l'exportation de produits laitiers - Recours des États-Unis et de la Nouvelle-Zélande à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord - AB-2001-6 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Canadá - Medidas que afectan a la importación de leche y a las exportaciones de productos lácteos - Recurso de Nueva Zelandia y los Estados Unidos al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - AB-2001-6 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: Canada – Dairy (Article 21.5 – New Zealand and US). I. Introduction  II. Arguments of the Participants and Third Participant  A. Claims of Error by Canada - Appellant  1. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "payments"  2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "financed by virtue of governmental action"  3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  and Article 3.1 of the SCM Agreement  B. Arguments of New Zealand - Appellee  1. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "payments"  2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "financed by virtue of governmental action"  3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  C. Arguments of the United States - Appellee  1. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "payments"  2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "financed by virtue of governmental action"  3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  and Article 3.1 of the SCM Agreement  D. Arguments of the European Communities - Third Participant  1. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "payments"  2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  - "financed by virtue of governmental action"  III. Issue Raised in this Appeal  IV. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture  A. "Payments"  B. "Financed By Virtue of Governmental Action"  V. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  VI. Article 3.1 of the  SCM Agreement  VII. Findings and Conclusions: For the reasons set forth in this Report, the Appellate Body reverses the Panel's findings, in paragraph 6.79 of the Panel Report, that the supply of CEM by domestic milk producers to domestic dairy processors involves "payments" on the export of milk "that are financed by virtue of governmental action" under Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture,  and, in consequence, reverses the Panel's finding in paragraph 7.1 of the Panel Report. However, in the light of the factual findings made by the Panel and the uncontested facts in the Panel record, the Appellate Body is unable to complete the analysis of the claims made by New Zealand and the United States under Articles 9.1(c) or 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture, or the claim made by the United States under Article 3.1 of the  SCM Agreement.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: milk

Article 3.1 of the  SCM Agreement  VII. Findings and Conclusions: For the reasons set forth in this Report, the Appellate Body reverses the Panel's findings, in paragraph 6.79 of the Panel Report, that the supply of CEM by domestic milk producers to domestic dairy processors involves "payments" on the export of milk "that are financed by virtue of governmental action" under Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture,  and, in consequence, reverses the Panel's finding in paragraph 7.1 of the Panel Report. However, in the light of the factual findings made by the Panel and the uncontested facts in the Panel record, the Appellate Body is unable to complete the analysis of the claims made by New Zealand and the United States under Articles 9.1(c) or 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture, or the claim made by the United States under Article 3.1 of the  SCM Agreement.

title_en: United States - Tax Treatment for "Foreign Sales Corporations" - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by the European Communities - Report of the Panel
title_fr: États-Unis - Traitement fiscal des sociétés de ventes à l'étranger - Recours des Communautés européennes à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Trato fiscal aplicado a las empresas de ventas en el extranjero - Recurso de las Comunidades Europeas al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents: Short title: US - FSC. I.Procedural background II. Factual aspects. III. Findings requested by the Parties. IV. Arguments of the parties. V. Arguments of the Third parties. VI. Procedural matters. VII. Interim review. A. Original comments by the European Communities. B. Original comments by the United States. VIII. Findings. A. Panel's approach to examination of EC claims in this dispute. B. Requirement of "use outside the United States". 1. Claims under Article 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement. 2. Footnote 59. 3. Claim under Article 3.2 of the SCM Agreement. 4. Claims under the Agreement on Agriculture. C. Foreign articles/labour limitation. 1. Claim under Article III:4 of the GATT 1994. (i) whether the imported and domestic products at issue are "like products" (ii) whether the Act is a "law, regulation or requirement affecting the internal … use" of imported and like domestic products by reason of the foreign articles/labour limitation (iii) whether the Act accords imported products "less favourable" treatment than that accorded to like domestic products by reason of the foreign articles/labour limitation. 2. Other claims. D. Transitional issues. IX. Conclusion: In light of the findings contained in Section VIII above, we therefore conclude that: (a) the Act is inconsistent with Article 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement as it involves subsidies "contingent… upon export performance" within the meaning of Article 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement by reason of the requirement of "use outside the United States" and fails to fall within the scope of the fifth sentence of footnote 59 of the SCM Agreement because it is not a measure to avoid the double taxation of foreign-source income within the meaning of footnote 59 of the SCM Agreement; (b) the United States has acted inconsistently with its obligation under Article 3.2 of the SCM Agreement not to maintain subsidies referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 3 of the SCM Agreement.

contents: Short title: US - FSC. I. Introduction  II. Background  A. Overview of United States Rules of Taxation  B. ETI Act  III. Arguments of the Participants and Third Participants  A. Claims of Error by the United States - Appellant  1. Subsidies Contingent Upon Export under the  SCM Agreement  2. Export Subsidies under the Agreement on Agriculture  3. Article III:4 of the GATT 1994  4. Withdrawal of the FSC Subsidies  B. Arguments of the European Communities - Appellee  1. Subsidies Contingent Upon Export under the  SCM Agreement  2. Export Subsidies under the Agreement on Agriculture  3. Article III:4 of the GATT 1994  4. Withdrawal of the FSC Subsidies  C. Claims of Error by the European Communities - Appellant  1. Article 10.3 of the DSU:  Third Party Rights  2. Conditional Appeals  D. Arguments of the United States - Appellee  1. Article 10.3 of the DSU:  Third Party Rights  2. Conditional Appeals  E. Arguments of the Third Participants  1. Australia  2. Canada  3. India  4. Japan  IV. Issues Raised in this Appeal  V. Article 1.1 of the  SCM Agreement:  "Foregoing Revenue" that is "Otherwise Due"  VI. Article 3.1(a) of the  SCM Agreement:  Export Contingency  VII. Footnote 59 to the  SCM Agreement:  Avoiding Double Taxation of Foreign-Source Income  VIII. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture:  Export Subsidies  IX. Article III:4 of the GATT 1994  A. Law, Regulation or Requirement Affecting the Internal Use of Imported and Like Domestic Products  B. "Less Favourable Treatment"  X. Article 4.7 of the  SCM Agreement:  Withdrawal of FSC Subsidies  XI. Article 10.3 of the DSU  XII. Conditional Appeals  XIII. Findings and Conclusions.  The Appellate Body  recommends  that the DSB request the United States to bring the ETI measure, found in this Report, and in the Panel Report as modified by this Report, to be inconsistent with its obligations under Article 3.1(a) of the  SCM Agreement,  under Articles 3.3, 8 and 10.1 of the Agreement on Agriculture,  and under Article III:4 of the GATT 1994, into conformity with its obligations under those Agreements, and that the DSB request the United States to implement fully the recommendations and rulings of the DSB in  US - FSC,  made pursuant to Article 4.7 of the SCM Agreement.

title_en: Canada - Measures Affecting the Importation of Milk and the Exportation of Dairy Products - Second Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by New Zealand and the United States - AB-2002-6 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Canada - Mesures visant l'importation de lait et l'exportation de produits laitiers - Deuxième recours des États-Unis et de la Nouvelle-Zélande à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord - AB-2002-6 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Canadá - Medidas que afectan a la importación de leche y a las exportaciones de productos lácteos - Segundo recurso de Nueva Zelandia y los Estados Unidos al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - AB-2002-6 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Canada – Dairy (Article 21.5 – New Zealand and US II). I. Introduction. II. Background. III. Written arguments of the participants and the third participants. A. Claims of error by Canada - appellant. 1. Article 10.3 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-rules of evidence. 2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"payments financed by virtue of governmental action". (a) "payments". (b) "financed by virtue of governmental action". 3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"export subsidies". B. Written arguments of New Zealand - Appellee. 1. Article 10.3 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-rules of evidence. 2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"payments financed by virtue of governmental action". (a) "payments". (b) "financed by virtue of governmental action". 3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"export subsidies". C. Written arguments of the United States - Appellee. 1. Article 10.3 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-rules of evidence. 2. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"payments financed by virtue of governmental action". (a) "payments". (b) "financed by virtue of governmental action". 3. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"export subsidies". D. Written arguments of the third participants. 1. Argentina. 2. European Communities. IV. Issues raised in this appeal. V. Article 10.3 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-rules of evidence. VI. Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"payments financed by virtue of governmental action". A. "payments". 1. General remarks on Article 9.1(c) of the  Agreement on Agriculture. 2. Individual producer's costs of production or industry-wide average. 3. Imputed costs. 4. Selling costs. 5. Assessment of evidence. 6. Conclusion on "payments" under Article 9.1(c). B. "financed by virtue of governmental action". C. Conclusion on Article 9.1(c) of the Agreement on Agriculture. VII. Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture-"export subsidies". VIII. Findings and conclusions: The Appellate Body: (a) reverses the Panel's interpretation of Article 10.3 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  in paragraph 5.19 of the Panel Report, according to which a complaining Member would be required to make out a  prima facie  case in support of all aspects of its claims under Articles 3.3, 8, 9.1(c), and 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture,  but holds that this error did not vitiate the Panel's findings under Articles 3.3, 8, 9.1(c), and 10.1 of that Agreement; (b) upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraphs 5.89 and 5.135 of the Panel Report, that Canada, through the combination of the supply of CEM and the operation of Special Milk Class 5(d), has acted inconsistently with its obligations under Article 3.3 and Article 8 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  by providing export subsidies listed in Article 9.1(c) of that Agreement in excess of the quantity commitment levels specified in Canada's Schedule;  and (c) declines to rule on the Panel's alternative finding under Article 10.1 of the  Agreement on Agriculture  in paragraph 5.165 of the Panel Report, as, in the light of the Appellate Body's finding in subparagraph (b) above, that alternative finding is moot and of no legal effect.

title_en: Thailand - Anti-Dumping Duties on Angles, Shapes and Sections of Iron or Non-Alloy Steel and H-Beams from Poland - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Thaïlande - Droits antidumping sur les profilés en fer ou en aciers non alliés et les poutres en H en provenance de Pologne - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Tailandia - Derechos antidumping sobre los perfiles de hierro y acero sin alear y vigas doble T procedentes de Polonia - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Thailand - H-Beams. 
I. Introduction. II. Factual aspects. III. Parties' requests for findings and recommendations. A. Poland. B. Thailand. IV. Arguments of the Parties. A. Main arguments of the Parties. B. Arguments concerning submission of certain confidential information. V. Submission of certain confidential information by thailand. VI. Interim review. A. Comments by Poland. B. Comments by Thailand. VII. Reasoning and findings. A. Preliminary issues. B. General remarks. C. Evaluation of claims. D. Article 6 ad. VIII. Conclusions and recommendation: We conclude that Poland failed to establish that Thailand's initiation of the anti-dumping investigation on imports of H-beams from Poland was inconsistent with the requirements of Articles 5.2, 5.3 and 5.5 of the AD Agreement or Article VI of the GATT 1994. We conclude that Poland failed to establish that Thailand has acted inconsistently with its obligations under Article 2 of the AD Agreement or Article VI of the GATT 1994 in the calculation of the amount for profit in constructing normal value. We conclude that Thailand's imposition of the definitive anti-dumping measure on imports of H-beams from Poland is inconsistent with the requirements of Article 3 AD Agreement. Under Article 3.8 of the DSU, in cases where there is infringement of the obligations assumed under a covered agreement, the action is considered prima facie to constitute a case of nullification or impairment of benefits under that agreement. Accordingly, we conclude that to the extent Thailand has acted inconsistently with the provisions of the AD Agreement, it has nullified or impaired benefits accruing to Poland under that Agreement. We recommend that the Dispute Settlement Body request Thailand to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under the AD Agreement.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: steel products (non-alloy)

Conclusions and recommendation: We conclude that Poland failed to establish that Thailand's initiation of the anti-dumping investigation on imports of H-beams from Poland was inconsistent with the requirements of Articles 5.2, 5.3 and 5.5 of the AD Agreement or Article VI of the GATT 1994. We conclude that Poland failed to establish that Thailand has acted inconsistently with its obligations under Article 2 of the AD Agreement or Article VI of the GATT 1994 in the calculation of the amount for profit in constructing normal value. We conclude that Thailand's imposition of the definitive anti-dumping measure on imports of H-beams from Poland is inconsistent with the requirements of Article 3 AD Agreement. Under Article 3.8 of the DSU, in cases where there is infringement of the obligations assumed under a covered agreement, the action is considered prima facie to constitute a case of nullification or impairment of benefits under that agreement. Accordingly, we conclude that to the extent Thailand has acted inconsistently with the provisions of the AD Agreement, it has nullified or impaired benefits accruing to Poland under that Agreement. We recommend that the Dispute Settlement Body request Thailand to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under the AD Agreement.

title_en: European Communities - Anti-Dumping Duties on Imports of Cotton-Type Bed Linen from India - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by India - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Communautés européennes - Droits antidumping sur les importations de linge de lit en coton en provenance d'Inde - Recours de l'Inde à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Derechos antidumping sobre las importaciones de ropa de cama de algodón originarias de la India - Recurso de la India al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents: Short title: EC - Bed Linen (Article 21.5 - India)"),  -- I. Introduction. II. Factual aspects. III. Parties' requests for findings and recommendations. A. India. B. The European Communities. IV. Arguments of the Parties. V. Arguments of the third Parties. VI. Findings. A. General issues. B. Request for preliminary rulings. C. Claims and arguments. VII. Conclusions and recommendation: "In light of the findings above, we conclude that the EC's definitive anti-dumping measure on imports of bed linen from India, EC Regulation 1644/2001, is not inconsistent with the AD Agreement or the DSU. We therefore consider that the EC has implemented the recommendation of the original Panel, the Appellate Body, and the DSB to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under the AD Agreement. In the light of our conclusions, we make no recommend ations under Article 19.1 of the DSU."
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: bed linen

title_en: Mexico - Anti-Dumping Investigation of High Fructose Corn Syrup (HFCS) from the United States - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by the United States - AB-2001-5 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Mexique - Enquête antidumping concernant le sirop de maïs à haute teneur en fructose (SHTF) en provenance des États-Unis - Recours des États-Unis à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - AB-2001-5 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: México - Investigación antidumping sobre el jarabe de maíz con alta concentración de fructosa (JMAF) procedente de los Estados Unidos - Recurso de los Estados Unidos al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - AB-2001-5 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: Mexico - Corn Syrup. I. Introduction. II. Arguments of the participants and the third participant. A. Claims of error by Mexico - appellant. 1. The panel's treatment of alleged deficiencies in the proceedings. 2. Article 3 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "threat of material injury". 3. Article 12.7 of the DSU and Article 17.6 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "reasoning of the panel". B. Arguments of the United States - Appellee. 1. The panel's treatment of alleged deficiencies in the proceedings. 2. Article 3 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "threat of material injury". 3. Article 12.7 of the DSU and Article 17.6 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "reasoning of the panel". C. Arguments of the third participant. 1. European Communities. III. Issues raised in this appeal. IV. The panel's treatment of alleged deficiencies in the proceedings. A. Mexico's conduct before the panel and the consequences. B. The nature of Mexico's "objections". V. Article 3 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "threat of material injury". A. Likelihood of increased imports. B. Likely impact of imports on the domestic industry. VI. Article 12.7 of the DSU and Article 17.6 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "reasoning of the panel". A. Article 12.7 of the DSU: "basic rationale". 1. The panel's finding concerning Article 3.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement. 2. The panel's finding concerning Article 3.1 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement. B. Article 17.6(ii) of the Anti-Dumping Agreement: "permissible interpretation". VII. Findings and conclusions: The Appellate Body  recommends that the DSB request that Mexico bring its anti-dumping measure found in this Report, and in the Panel Report as upheld by this Report, to be inconsistent with the Anti-Dumping Agreement, into conformity with its obligations under that Agreement.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: syrups (fructose)

title_en: Mexico - Anti-Dumping Investigation of High Fructose Corn Syrup (HFCS) from the United States - Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by the United States - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Mexique - Enquête antidumping concernant le sirop de maïs à haute teneur en fructose (SHFT) en provenance des États-Unis - Recours des États-Unis à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: México - Investigación antidumping sobre el jarabe de maíz con alta concentración de fructosa procedente de los Estados Unidos - Recurso de los Estados Unidos al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents: Short title: Mexico - Corn Syrup. I.Introduction and factual background. II. Findings and recommendations requested by the Parties. III. Main arguments of the parties   A. first written submission of the United States. 1. SECOFI disregarded the panel's conclusion that it made an insufficient finding of the likelihood of increased imports. 2. SECOFI did not address the DSB's rulings regarding the analysis of the likely impact of the dumped imports. 3. SECOFI did not adequately explain its analysis in critical respects.  B. First written submission of Mexico. 1. Introduction. 2. Mexico has complied with the recommendations and rulings of the Dispute Settlement Body. 3. Conclusion. C. Second written submission of the United States. 1. SECOFI's finding of likelihood of increased imports was based on conjecture rather than evidence. 2. SECOFI did not adequately analyze the likely impact of the dumped imports. 3. SECOFI did not adequately explain its analysis in critical respects. D. Second written submission of Mexico. 1. Introduction. 2. Mexico complied with the conclusions and recommendation of the panel and the Dispute Settlement Body. 3. Conclusions. E. Oral statement of the United States. 1. The restraint Agreement and Article 3.7(i). 2. Analysis of likely impact and Article 3.4. 3. Notice and Article 12. F. Oral statement of Mexico. 1. SECOFI examined the probable impact of corn syrup (HFCS) imports on the domestic industry and determined threat of injury on the basis of the industry as a whole. 2. Effects of the restraint agreement on the likelihood of substantially increased importation. 3. Mexico complied with the provisions of Articles 12.2 and 12.2.2 of the AD agreement   4. Conclusion. IV. Arguments of the Third Parties.  A. Oral statement of the European Communities   B. Joint statement of Jamaica and Mauritius. V. Interim review. VI. Findings. A. Introduction. B. Finding of Likelihood of Increased Imports. C. Analysis of likely impact of imports on the domestic industry. D. Adequacy of notice of redetermination. VII. Conclusions and recommendation. It has been concluded that Mexico's imposition of definitive anti-dumping duties on imports of HFCS from the United States on the basis of the SECOFI redetermination is inconsistent with the requirements of the AD Agreement in that Mexico's inadequate consideration of the impact of dumped imports on the domestic industry, and its inadequate consideration of the potential effect of the alleged restraint agreement in its determination of likelihood of substantially increased importation, are not consistent with the provisions of Articles 3.1, 3.4, 3.7 and 3.7(i) of the AD Agreement.  Mexico has failed to implement the recommendation of the original Panel and the DSU to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under the AD Agreement. Under Article 3.8 of the DSU, in cases where there is infringement of the obligations assumed under a covered agreement, the action is considered prima facie to constitute a case of nullification or impairment of benefits under that agreement. Mexico has acted inconsistently with the provisions of the AD Agreement, it has nullified or impaired benefits accruing to the United States under that Agreement.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: syrups (fructose)

title_en: India - Measures Affecting the Automotive Sector - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Inde - Mesures concernant le secteur automobile - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: India - Medidas que afectan al sector del automóvil - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: India - Autos.
Recommendations: In accordance with the terms of Article 3.8 of the DSU, the Panel notes that the violations by India of its obligations under the GATT 1994 is considered prima facie to constitute a case of nullification and impairment of benefits under that Agreement, and that this has not been rebutted. 
The Panel consequently recommends that the DSB request India to bring its measures into conformity with its obligations under the WTO Agreements.

title_en: Argentina - Measures Affecting the Export of Bovine Hides and the Import of Finished Leather - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Argentine - Mesures visant l'exportation de peaux de bovins et l'importation de cuirs finis - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Argentina - Medidas que afectan a la exportación de pieles de bovino y a la importación de cueros acabados - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Argentina - Hides and Leather. 
Procedural background. Factual aspects (measures on export of bovine hides): Scope of the claim. The products concerned: production and processing of raw and semi-tanned hides. Production, price, and trade figures of raw hides, semi-finished and finished leather. Context of government measures regarding the export of raw bovine hides in Argentina. Resolution 2235. The practical application of Resolution 2235/96. Claims by the parties. Main arguments. Violation of Article XI:1 of the GATT 1994. Violation of Article X:3 (A) of the GATT 1994. Third party submission by the United States. Factual aspects (tax measures on imports): the IVA. Advances on the IVA. The IG. Advances on the IG. Claims by the parties. Main arguments: Article III:2 of the GATT 1994. General exception of Artivle XX of the GATT 1994. Third party submission by the United States. Interim review: Background. Claim under Article X:3(A) of the GATT 1994. Claim under Article III:2, first sentence, of the GATT 1994. Defence under Article XX(D) of the GATT 1994. Findings: Claim under Article XI:1 of the GATT 1994. Claim under Article X:3(a) of the GATT 1994. Claims under Article III:2, first sentence, of the GATT 1994. Conclusions.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: skins, furs and pelts

title_en: Guatemala - Definitive Anti-Dumping Measures on Grey Portland Cement from Mexico - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Guatemala - Mesures antidumping définitives concernant le ciment Portland gris en provenance du Mexique - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Guatemala - Medida antidumping definitiva aplicada al cemento Portland gris procedente de México - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Guatemala - Cement II. 
Introduction: Background. Establishment and composition of the Panel. Panel proceedings.  Factual aspects.  Findings and recommendations requested by the parties: Mexico. Guatemela.  Preliminary objections: The Panel was improperly composed and is not competent to examine the matter before it. Consideration by this Panel of previous panel report. Preliminary objection to Panel consideration of the provsional measure and the complaints related thereto. Third party arguments: Ecuador. El Salvador. European Communities. Honduras. United States. Main arguments of the parties concerning issues arising under the AD Agreement and GATT 1994: Standard of review and burden of proof. Initiation of the anti-dumping invstigation. Guatemala's notification of the initiation of the investigation. Guatemala's application of the provisional measure. Conduct of the anti-dumping investigation by Guatemala. Guatemala's final affirmative determination. Are any errors Guatemala might be found to have committed insufficient to justify the formulation of a recommendation by the Panel ? Should the Panel decline to suggest that Guatemala revoke the definitive anti-dumping measure or refund the anti-dumping duties collected ? Interim review. Findings: Introduction. Preliminary issues raised by Guatemala. Claims by Mexico concerning the initiation of the investigation. Alleged procedural violations during the course of the investigation. Alleged violations concerning the fnal determination. Claims by Mexico concerning the provisional anti-dumping measure. Conclusions and recommendation.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: cement (Portland)

contents: Short title: US - Lamb. I. Introduction. II. Arguments of the Participants and Third Participant. A. Claims of Error by the United States - Appellant. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Domestic Industry. 3. Threat of Serious Injury. 4. Causation. B. Arguments of Australia - Appellee. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Domestic Industry. 3. Threat of Serious Injury. 4. Causation. C. Arguments of New Zealand - Appellee. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Domestic Industry. 3. Threat of Serious Injury. 4. Causation. D. Claims of Error by Australia - Appellant. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Threat of Serious Injury. (a) Standard of Review. (b) Evaluation of Relevant Factors. 3. Conditional Appeals. E. Claims of Error by New Zealand - Appellant. 1. Threat of Serious Injury. (a) Standard of Review. (b) Evaluation of Relevant Factors. 2. Judicial Economy. 3. Conditional Appeals. F. Arguments of the United States - Appellee. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Threat of Serious Injury. (a) Standard of Review. (b) Evaluation of Relevant Factors. 3. Judicial Economy. 4. Conditional Appeals. G. Arguments of the European Communities - Third Participant. 1. Unforeseen Developments. 2. Causation. III. Issues Raised in this Appeal. IV. Unforeseen Developments. V. Domestic Industry. VI. Threat of Serious Injury. A. Standard of Review. B. The Determination of a "Threat of Serious Injury". 1. Background. 2. Meaning of the Term "Threat of Serious Injury". 3. Evaluation of Relevant Factors under Article 4.2(a) of the Agreement on Safeguards. (a) Sufficiency of the Data. (b) Temporal focus of the data evaluation. 4. Panel's Review of the USITC's Determination of a "Threat of Serious Injury". VII. Causation. VIII. Judicial Economy. IX. Conditional Appeals. X. Findings and Conclusions.

title_en: Argentina - Definitive Anti-Dumping Measures on Imports of Ceramic Floor Tiles from Italy - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Argentine - Mesures antidumping définitives à l'importation de carreaux de sol en céramique en provenance d'Italie - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Argentina - Medidas antidumping definitivas aplicadas a las importaciones de baldosas de cerámica para el suelo procedentes de Italia - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Argentina - Ceramic Tiles. 
I. Introduction. II. Factual aspects. III. Parties' requests for findings and recommendations.  A. The European Communities.  B. Argentina. IV. Arguments of the parties and third parties. A. Claim under Article 6.8 of the AD Agreement.  B. Claim under Article 6.10 of the AD Agreement. C. Claim under Article 2.4 of the AD Agreement. D. Claim under Article 6.9 of the AD Agreement. V. Interim review  VI. Findings. A. Standard of review. B. Burden of proof. C. Factual introduction. D. Claim 1: Facts available under Article 6.8 and Annex II of the AD Agreement. E. Claim 2: Article 6.10: requirement to calculate individual margins of dumping for all exporters included in the sample  F. Claim 3: Article 2.4: the need to make adjustments for differences in physical characteristics. G. Claim 4: Article 6.9: Failure to inform the exporters of the "essential facts" on which the decision is based.  VII. conclusions and recommendation: Under Article 3.8 of the DSU, in cases where there is infringement of the obligations assumed under a covered agreement, the action is considered prima facie to constitute a case of nullification or impairment of benefits under that agreement.  Argentina has failed to adduce any evidence to rebut this presumption.  Accordingly, we conclude that, to the extent Argentina has acted inconsistently with the provisions of the AD Agreement, it has nullified or impaired benefits accruing to the EC under that Agreement. We recommend that the Dispute Settlement Body request Argentina to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under the AD Agreement.

document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: ceramic tiles
