title_en: United States - Definitive Safeguard Measures on Imports of Circular Welded Carbon Quality Line Pipe from Korea - AB-2001-9 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: États-Unis - Mesures de sauvegarde définitives à l'importation de tubes et tuyaux de qualité carbone soudés, de section circulaire, en provenance de Corée - AB-2001-9 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Medida de salvaguardia definitiva contra las importaciones de tubos al carbono soldados de sección circular procedentes de Corea - AB-2001-9 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: US - Line Pipe. I. Introduction and factual background. II. Arguments of the participants and third participants. A. Claims of error by the United States - Appellant. B. Arguments of Korea - Appellee. C. Claims of error by Korea - Appellant. D. Arguments of the United States - Appellee. E. Arguments of the third participants. III. Issues raised in this appeal. IV. Introductory remarks. V. Adequate opportunity for prior consultations. VI. Obligation to endeavour to maintain a substantially equivalent level of concessions and other obligations. VII. Exclusion of "de minimis" developing country exporters from the line pipe measure. VIII. Necessity of a discrete determination either of serious injury or of threat of serious injury. IX. "Parallelism" between the investigation and the application of the line pipe measure. X. Non-attribution of the injurious effects of other factors to increased imports. XI. The application of the line pipe measure:  express justification and permissible extent. A. The express justification of the line pipe measure at the time of application. B. The permissible extent of the line pipe measure. XII. Findings and conclusions (herewith abbreviated): The Appellate Body: upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.1(7) of the Panel Report, that the United States acted inconsistently with its obligation under Article 12.3 of the  Agreement on Safeguards; upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.1(8) of the Panel Report, that the United States acted inconsistently with its obligation under Article 8.1 of the Agreement on Safeguards; upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.1(5) of the Panel Report, that the United States did not comply with its obligation under Article 9.1 of the  Agreement on Safeguards; reverses the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.1(3) of the Panel Report, that the United States acted inconsistently with its obligations under Articles 3.1 and 4.2(c) of the  Agreement on Safeguards; reverses the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.2(9) of the Panel Report, that the United States did not violate its obligations under Articles 2 and 4 of the  Agreement on Safeguards; modifies the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.2(10) of the Panel Report, that the United States did not violate its obligations under Articles I, XIII:1 and XIX of GATT 1994; upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.1(4) of the Panel Report, that the United States acted inconsistently with its obligation under Article 4.2(b) of the Agreement on Safeguards; upholds the Panel's finding, in paragraph 7.81 of the Panel Report, that the United States was not required by Article 5.1, first sentence, of the  Agreement on Safeguards  to demonstrate, at the time of imposition, that the line pipe measure was necessary to prevent or remedy serious injury and to facilitate adjustment; reverses the Panel's finding, in paragraph 8.2(2) of the Panel Report, that Korea failed to make a  prima facie  case that the United States violated its obligation under Article 5.1, first sentence, of the  Agreement on Safeguards.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: line pipe

title_fr: États-Unis - Mesure de sauvegarde transitoire appliquée aux fils de coton peignés en provenance du Pakistan - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Medida de salvaguardia de transición aplicada a los hilados peinados de algodón procedentes del Pakistán - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: US - Cotton Yarn. 
I. Introduction.  II. Factual aspects.  III. Claims by the parties.  IV. Arguments of the parties.  A. General arguments. 1. The basic questions before the panel.  2. Relevance of other WTO jurisprudence  B. The interpretation of article 6.2 of the ATC .  1. The General Issue . 2. Views on the Plain Meaning of Article 6.2. 3. Identification of the Domestic Industry  4. The Interpretation of the Term "like and/or directly competitive products". (a) Approaches to identification of the industry in terms of "like and/or directly competitive products". (b) Views on the term "like but not directly competitive products". (c) Discussion of the term "directly competitive. (d) Discussion of the term "directly competitive or substitutable". (e) The term "like and/or directly competitive products" as used in the MFA.  C. The determination by the United States of serious damage, or actual threat thereof (article 6.3 of the ATC)  1. The United States Determination of Serious Damage to the Domestic Industry.  2. The Nature of the Data Used and the Data Verification Process.  3. The Arguments Concerning Plant Closures. D. Demonstrating the causal link between imports and serious damage.  E. Attribution of serious damage, or actual threat thereof (article 6.4 of the ATC).  1. The Attribution of Serious Damage, or Actual Threat Thereof, to Pakistan. 2. The Question of the Need for a Comparative Assessment of  Imports from Mexico F. The question of the need for a prospective analysis  to determine actual threat of serious damage. G. Discussion of the TMB review of this matter .  H. The late submission of evidence. I. Concluding comments. V. Arguments presented by Third Parties.  A. Participation of the European communities B. The submission of India. VI. Interim review  A. General.  B. Comments of  Pakistan. C. Comments of the United States. VII. Findings.  A. Claims by the parties  B. Descriptive part issue. C. Relevant provisions of the WTO Agreement  D. General issues of interpretation  E. Definition of domestic industry. F. Finding of serious damage. G. Investigation period, including period for determining serious damage and causation. H. Attribution. I. Actual threat of serious damage. VIII. Conclusions and recommendations. The Panel has concluded that the transitional safeguard measure (quantitative restriction) imposed by the United States on imports of combed cotton yarn from Pakistan as of 17 March 1999, and extended as of 17 March 2000 for a further year is inconsistent with the provisions of Article 6 of the ATC.

title_en: United States - Definitive Safeguard Measures on Imports of Circular Welded Carbon Quality Line Pipe from Korea - Report of the Panel
title_fr: États-Unis - Mesures de sauvegarde définitives à l'importation de tubes et tuyaux de qualité carbone soudés, de section circulaire, en provenance de Corée - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Medida de salvaguardia definitiva contra las importaciones de tubos al carbono soldados de sección circular procedentes de Corea - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: US - Line Pipe. 
I. Introduction. II. Factual aspects. III. Parties' requests for findings and recommendations. IV. Arguments of the Parties. V. Arguments of the third Parties. VI. Interim review. VII. Findings. VIII. Conclusions and recommendation: The US line pipe measure was imposed inconsistently with certain provisions of GATT 1994 and/or the Safeguards Agreement but some of Korea's claims were rejected. It is concluded that to the extent that the United States has acted inconsistently with the provisions of the Agreement on Safeguards and GATT 1994, it has nullified or impaired the benefits accruing to Korea under the Agreement on Safeguards and GATT 1994. It is therefore recommended that the Dispute Settlement Body request the United States to bring its line pipe measure into conformity with its obligations under the WTO Agreement on Safeguards and the GATT of 1994. Korea's request for a specific suggestion by the Panel on ways in which the United States may implement the recommendation made in this report was declined.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: line pipe

contents:
Short title: EC - Sardines.

title_en: European Communities - Trade Description of Sardines - AB-2002-3 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Communautés européennes - Désignation commerciale des sardines - AB-2002-3 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Denominación comercial de sardinas - AB-2002-3 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: EC - Sardines. The Appellate Body, in a report (DS231/AB/R) issued by the WTO on 26 September 2002, has upheld the panel's findings that the European Communities' regulation on the trade description of sardines is inconsistent with the WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade. I. Introduction II. Arguments of the Participants and the Third Participants A. Claims of Error by the European Communities - Appellant B .Arguments of Peru - Appellee C. Arguments of the Third Participants III. Issues Raised in this Appeal IV. Procedural Issues V. The Characterization of the EC Regulation as a "Technical Regulation" VI. The Temporal Scope of Application of Article 2.4 of the TBT Agreement VII. The Characterization of Codex Stan 94 as a "Relevant International Standard" A. The European Communities' Argument that Consensus is Required B. The European Communities' Argument on the Product Coverage of Codex Stan 94 VIII. Whether Codex Stan 94 Was Used "As a Basis For" the EC Regulation IX. The Question of the "Ineffectiveness or Inappropriateness" of Codex Stan 94 A. The Burden of Proof B. Whether Codex Stan 94 is an Effective and Appropriate Means to Fulfil the "Legitimate Objectives" Pursued by the European Communities Through the EC  Regulation X. The Objectivity of the Assessment of Certain Facts by the Panel XI. The References in the Panel Report to Trade-Restrictiveness XII. Completing the Legal Analysis XIII. Findings  and Conclusions
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: sardines

title_en: Canada - Export Credits and Loan Guarantees for Regional Aircraft - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Canada - Crédits à l'exportation et garanties de prêts accordés pour les aéronefs régionaux - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Canadá - Créditos a la exportación y garantías de préstamos para las aeronaves regionales - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: Canada - Aircraft Credits and Guarantees.
Canada - Export Credits and Loan Guarantees for Regional Aircraft. I. Introduction. A. Complaint of Brazil. B. Establishment and composition of the Panel. C. Panel proceedings. II. Factual aspects. III. Parties' requests for findings and recommendations  IV. Arguments of the Parties. V. Arguments of the third parties. VI. Interim review  VII. Findings. A. Introduction.  B. preliminary issues  1. Disputes over implementation - Article 21.5 of the DSU (regarding claims 1, 2, and 3 of Brazil)  2. Specificity of the Request for the Establishment of a Panel - Article 6.2 of the DSU (regarding claims 1, 2, 5, and 7 of Brazil)  C. programmes "as such"  1. Mandatory/discretionary distinction  2. Export Development Corporation "as such"  3. Investissement Québec "as such"  D. EDC / IQ "as applied"  E. information gathering by the panel  F. canada account support for the air wisconsin transaction  1. Is the Canada Account financing to Air Wisconsin an export subsidy?  2. Does the Canada Account financing to Air Wisconsin fall within the item (k) safe haven?  3. Conclusion  G. other edc transactions  1. Brazil's general "benefit" arguments  2. Brazil's transaction-specific "benefit" arguments  3. Is the EDC's Corporate Account financing to Comair "contingent … upon export performance"?  4. Is the EDC's Canada Account financing to Air Nostrum "contingent … upon export performance"?  5. Conclusion  H. IQ equity guarantees  1. Are IQ equity guarantees "financial contributions"  2. Do the IQ equity guarantees confer a "benefit"?  3. Are IQ equity guarantees "contingent … upon export performance"?  4. Conclusion  I. IQ loan guarantees  VIII. Conclusions and recommendation:  Pursuant to Article 3.8 of the DSU, the findings in sub-paragraphs (e), (f) and (g) of the preceding paragraph also constitute a case of prima facie nullification or impairment of benefits accruing to Brazil under the SCM Agreement, which Canada has not rebutted.
In light of the above findings, we are required to make the recommendation provided for in Article 4.7 of the SCM Agreement.  Accordingly, we recommend that Canada withdraw the subsidies identified above without delay. Article 4.7 further provides that "the panel shall specify in its recommendation the time-period within which the measure must be withdrawn."  In other words, we are required to specify what period would represent withdrawal "without delay".  Taking into account the procedures that may be required to implement our recommendation on the one hand, and the requirement that Canada withdraw its subsidies "without delay" on the other, we conclude that Canada shall withdraw the subsidies identified in sub-paragraphs (e), (f), and (g) of paragraph 8.1 within 90 days.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: aircraft

Conclusions and recommendation:  Pursuant to Article 3.8 of the DSU, the findings in sub-paragraphs (e), (f) and (g) of the preceding paragraph also constitute a case of prima facie nullification or impairment of benefits accruing to Brazil under the SCM Agreement, which Canada has not rebutted.
In light of the above findings, we are required to make the recommendation provided for in Article 4.7 of the SCM Agreement.  Accordingly, we recommend that Canada withdraw the subsidies identified above without delay. Article 4.7 further provides that "the panel shall specify in its recommendation the time-period within which the measure must be withdrawn."  In other words, we are required to specify what period would represent withdrawal "without delay".  Taking into account the procedures that may be required to implement our recommendation on the one hand, and the requirement that Canada withdraw its subsidies "without delay" on the other, we conclude that Canada shall withdraw the subsidies identified in sub-paragraphs (e), (f), and (g) of paragraph 8.1 within 90 days.

contents:
Short title: US - Steel Safeguards.

title_fr: États-Unis - Mesures de sauvegarde définitives à l'importation de certains produits en acier - Rapports du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Medidas de salvaguardia definitivas sobre las importaciones de determinados productos de acero - Informes del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: US - Steel Safeguards.
I. Introduction. A. Factual background. II. WTO procedural aspects. A. Consultations under Article 12.3 of the Agreement on Safeguards. B. Dispute settlement consultations. C. Single panel under Article 9.1 of the DSU. III. Claims made by the complainants. A. European Communities. B. Japan. C. Korea. D. China. E. Switzerland. F. Norway. G. New Zealand. H. Brazil. IV. Conclusions, recommendations and suggestions requested by the complainants. A. European Communities. B. Japan. C. Korea. D. China. E. Switzerland. F. Norway. G. New Zealand. H. Brazil. V. Organizational meeting - request for preliminary rulings. VI. The panel's working procedures. VII. Arguments of the Parties. A. Condition of the us steel industry. B. Legal and analytical framework. C. Unforeseen developments. D. "a product". E. Definition of the domestic industry producing products that are like or directly competitive with the imported product. F. Increased imports. G. Serious injury or threat of serious injury. H. Causation. J. Article 7. K. Parallelism. L. Article 5.2 of the Agreement on safeguards and Article XIII of GATT 1994. M. Article 9.1 of the Agreement on safeguards (special and differential treatment). N. Article I:1 of the GATT 1994 and Article 2.2 of the Agreement on safeguards (non discrimination). O. Decision-making. VIII. Arguments of the third Parties. A. Canada. B. Cuba. C. Chinese Taipei. D. Mexico. E. Thailand. F. Turkey. G. Venezuela. IX. Interim review. A. Descriptive part. B. Panel's findings and conclusions. X. Findings. A. Introduction. B. General considerations for this dispute. C. Claims relating to unforeseen developments. D. Claims relating to increased imports. E. Claims relating to causation. F. Claims relating to parallelism. G. Additional findings. XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by the European Communities (WT/DS248). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by Japan (WT/DS249). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by Korea (WT/DS251). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by China (WT/DS252). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by Switzerland (WT/DS253). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by Norway (WT/DS254). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by New Zealand (WT/DS258). XI. Conclusions and recommendations on the claims by Brazil (WT/DS259).
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: steel products

title_en: United States - Subsidies on Upland Cotton - AB-2004-5 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: États-Unis - Subventions concernant le coton Upland - AB-2004-5 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Subvenciones al algodón americano (Upland) - AB-2004-5 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents:
Short title: US - Upland Cotton. 
I. Introduction. II. Arguments of the Participants and the Third Participants. A. Claims of Error by the United States - Appellant. B. Arguments of Brazil - Appellee. C. Claims of Error by Brazil - Appellant. D. Arguments of the United States - Appellee. E. Arguments of the Third Participants. III. Issues Raised in this Appeal. IV. Preliminary Issues. A. Terms of Reference - Expired Measures. B. Terms of Reference - Export Credit Guarantees. C. Statement of Available Evidence - Export Credit Guarantees. V. Domestic Support. A. Article 13(a) of the Agreement on Agriculture - Planting Flexibility Limitations. B. Article 13(a) of the Agreement on Agriculture - Base Period Update. C. Article 13(b) of the Agreement on Agriculture - Non-Green Box Domestic Support. VI. Serious Prejudice. A. Significant Price Suppression under Article 6.3(c) of the scm Agreement. B. World Market Share under Article 6.3(d) of the scm Agreement. VII. Import Substitution Subsidies and Export Subsidies. A. Step 2 Payments to Domestic Users. B. Step 2 Payments to Exporters. C. Export Credit Guarantees - Article 10.2 of the Agreement on Agriculture. D. Export Credit Guarantees - Burden of Proof. E. Export Credit Guarantees - Necessary Findings of Fact. F. Export Credit Guarantees - Circumvention. G. Export Credit Guarantees - Articles 1.1 and 3.1(a) of the SCM Agreement. H. ETI Act of 2000. I. Interpretation of Article Xvi:3 of the GATT 1994. VIII. Findings and Conclusions.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: cotton

title_en: United States - Sunset Reviews of Anti-Dumping Measures on Oil Country Tubular Goods from Argentina - AB-2004-4 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: États-Unis - Réexamens à l'extinction des mesures antidumping visant les produits tubulaires pour champs pétrolifères en provenance d'Argentine - AB-2004-4 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Estados Unidos - Exámenes por extinción de las medidas antidumping impuestas a los artículos tubulares para campos petrolíferos procedentes de la Argentina - AB-2004-4 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: Short title: US - Oil Country Tubular Goods Sunset Reviews. I. Introduction. II. Arguments of the Participants and Third Participants. III. Issues Raised in this Appeal. IV. The Panel's Terms of Reference. V. The Sunset Policy Bulletin. VI. Waiver Provisions of United States Laws and Regulations. VII. Factors to be Evaluated in a Likelihood-of-Injury Determination. VIII. Cumulation in Sunset Reviews. IX. The Panel's Interpretation of the Term "Likely". X. Consistency of the USITC's Determination with the Standard of "Likelihood" in Article 11.3 of the  Anti-Dumping Agreement. XI. The Timeframe in a Likelihood-of-Injury Determination. XII. Findings and Conclusions: The Appellate Body recommends that the Dispute Settlement Body request the United States to bring its measures found in the Panel Report, as modified by this Report, to be inconsistent with the  Anti-Dumping Agreement, into conformity with its obligations under that Agreement.
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: tubes (oil industry)

title_en: European Communities and Certain Member States - Measures Affecting Trade in Large Civil Aircraft - Report of the Panel
title_fr: Communautés européennes et certains États membres - Mesures affectant le commerce des aéronefs civils gros porteurs - Rapport du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas y determinados Estados miembros - Medidas que afectan al comercio de grandes aeronaves civiles - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: EC and certain member States - Large Civil Aircraft.
European Communities and Certain Member States - Measures Affecting Trade in Large Civil Aircraft - Report of the Panel.-- The panel concludes that, to the extent that the European Communities, France, Germany, Spain and the United Kingdom have acted inconsistently with the SCM Agreement, they have nullified or impaired benefits accruing to the United States under that Agreement. Additionally, the Panel recommends that the subsidizing Member granting each subsidy found to be prohibited withdraw it without delay and specify that this be done within 90 days.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: aircraft (civil)

title_en: European Communities and its Member States - Tariff Treatment of Certain Information Technology Products - Reports of the Panel
title_fr: Communautés européennes et leurs États membres - Traitement tarifaire de certains produits des technologies de l'information - Rapports du Groupe spécial
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas y sus Estados miembros - Trato arancelario otorgado a determinados productos de tecnología de la información - Informe del Grupo Especial
contents:
Short title: EC - IT Products. 
In the disputes WT/DS375, WT/DS376, and WT/DS377, as explained in paragraph 2.4 of the Panel's Findings, the Panel decided to issue its Reports in the form of a single document constituting three Panel Reports, each of the Reports relating to each one of the three complainants in this dispute.  The document comprises a common cover page, a common Descriptive Part and a common set of Findings in relation to the complainants' claims that the Panel decided to address.  This document also contains Conclusions and Recommendations that, unlike the Descriptive Part and the Findings, are particularised for each of the complainants.
doctype.name: Panel report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: Normal Report
document_product.product.name: high technology goods

title_en: European Communities - Definitive Anti-Dumping Measures on Certain Iron or Steel Fasteners from China - Recourse to article 21.5 of the DSU by China - 2015-7 - Report of the Appellate Body
title_fr: Comité du commerce et du développement - communautés européennes - Mesures antidumping définitives visant certains éléments de fixation en fer ou en acier en provenance de Chine - Recours de la Chine à l'article 21:5 du Mémorandum d'accord sur le règlement des différends - 2015-7 - Rapport de l'Organe d'appel
title_sp: Comunidades Europeas - Medidas antidumping definitivas sobre determinados elementos de fijación de hierro o acero procedentes de China - Recurso de China al párrafo 5 del artículo 21 del ESD - 2015-7 - Informe del Órgano de Apelación
contents: The European Union and China each appeals certain issues of law and legal interpretations developed in the Panel Report, European Communities – Definitive Anti-Dumping Measures on Certain Iron or Steel Fasteners from China – Recourse to Article 21.5 of the DSU by China   (Panel Report). The Panel was established pursuant to Article 21.5 of the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes (DSU) to consider a complaint by China  regarding the consistency with the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994 (Anti Dumping Agreement) and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994 (GATT 1994) of measures taken by the European Union to comply with the recommendations and rulings of the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) in the original proceedings in EC – Fasteners (China).
doctype.name: Appellate Body report
document_reporttype.reporttype.name: First Compliance Phase
document_product.product.name: steel products

contents:
Short Title: US - Tyres (China).
The Panel finds that in imposing the transitional safeguards measure on 26 September  2009 in respect of imports of subject tyres from China, the United States did not fail to comply with its obligations under Paragraph 16 of the Protocol and Articles I:1 and II:1 of the GATT 1994.
